<h1><a name="_Toc322168409"><span lang=EN-US>2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Introduction</span></a></h1>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168410"><span lang=EN-US>2.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Who is this written for?</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>PropForth is written for people who want to
interactively use and program Propeller based systems. It assumes you are
familiar with Propeller based hardware, and have some knowledge of the
Propeller architecture. </span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168411"><span lang=EN-US>2.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>What is PropForth?</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>PropForth runs on the propeller. It is an
interactive development and run time system. You can communicate with PropForth
using a standard serial port, or via ethernet and telnet depending on the
capabilities of the system you are using. It has a rich set of words which
allow you to quickly and easily manipulate the hardware interactively. It is easy
to program new words and use them in addition to the native set of words. Where
necessary, you can write new words in assembler code for fast execution.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>PropForth is outstanding for rapid
exploration and development. The interactive nature allows you to try new
things easily, verify functions, and allows for easy monitoring of hardware.
You can manipulate IO pins on one cog, and user another cog to monitor the
pins.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Each Propeller can run PropForth on up to 8
cogs, and you can concurrently interact with the cogs. Normal configuration
uses one cog for serial or ethernet communication allowing for up to 7
concurrent PropForth sessions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>It is based on the Forth programming
language, but it has been tuned for the propeller architecture and parallel
execution. PropForth does not prevent or protect you from manipulating the
propeller however you like. While it can be simple to use, it is also very
powerful.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168412"><span lang=EN-US>2.3<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Document Conventions</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>This document contains a lot of code
samples and the following are the conventions used.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>For Comments:</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ A code comment, frequently documenting
the stack use of the word.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The backslash denotes a comment.&nbsp; When
a backslash is encountered, the interpreter ignores the rest of the characters
on the line (the CR at the end of the line ends the comment).&nbsp; Comment
lines are green in this document. A comment is entered for each command word
definitions, and includes values needed on the stack (inputs), and the values
to be left on the stack (outputs).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>For text typed or pasted in at the prompt:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>1 3 -100</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Text to be typed or pasted into the command
line at the command prompt is blue in this document.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>For the output of the PropForth
interpreter, and user written words:</span></p>

<p class=Code><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Forth words are documented in the following
way. The text in the example input can be copied and pasted to a PropForth
terminal</span></p>

<h1><a name="_Toc322168417"><span lang=EN-US>3<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Getting started</span></a></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The best way to use this document is with a
running PropForth system. Use the examples to explore PropForth. At the end of
the getting started section, you will  have been introduced to a number of the
native PropForth words and you will be able to program new words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The sections which follow will then focus
on different topics and continue the exploration of PropForth.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168418"><span lang=EN-US>3.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Numbers</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>At the prompt, numbers can be entered in a
few ways.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>This is an example of both positive and
negative decimal numbers being entered. The _ (underscore) is available for
formatting. It is ignored when evaluating a number.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>1 3 -100 </span></p>

<p class=Code><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Entering a hexadecimal number, often
useful, is done by preceding the number with an h. Once again the _
(underscore) is ignored. Note that only caps are used in hexadecimal numbers.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>h100 h-100 hFFFF_FFFF</span></p>

<p class=Code><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Binary numbers are preceded with a b.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>b_1001_0011 b0010</span></p>

<p class=Code><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Decimal numbers are default at boot, but
they can be entered explicitly by preceding the number with a d.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>d_1 d3 d-100</span></p>

<p class=Code><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Remember, Hex digits are always UPPERCASE
letters A, B, C, D, E, and F; and the number base designators b, d, and h (for
binary, decimal, and hex) are always lowercase.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Most variables in PropForth are 16bit
variables. This save a lot of space in PropForth, but a 16 bit variable is a
positive number between 0 and 65,535. For many uses this is adequate. If you
need positive numbers larger than 65,535 or you need negative numbers, you must
use longs. PropForth words treat numbers on the stack as signed long numbers by
default.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168419"><span lang=EN-US>3.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Words</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The PropForth interpreter can understand
numbers and words. Words and numbers are delimited by blanks. Word names are up
to 31 characters, and can contain any sequence of characters, symbols, and
letters. PropForth is extended by programming new words. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The core set of PropForth words includes
words like + - * / .</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When a new word is defined it can use other
words. So a word is really a sequence of other words.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>At the low level, some words are a sequence
of assembler instruction codes. These are generally native PropForth words. We
will see later how we can program words, and later still how we can program
assembler words</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168420"><span lang=EN-US>3.3<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Stack</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When you enter a number at the prompt,
PropForth puts the numbers on a stack. The stack can hold up to 32 32-bit
numbers, but the PropForth interpreter code uses the stack as well. The
pragmatic limit of numbers on the stack is about 24.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Each cog has its own stack in cog memory.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To see what is on the stack we can use the
st? word.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>1 3 h-100 st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_003
-0_000_000_256</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>By convention the stack is represented with
the bottom of the stack on the left and the top of the stack on the right.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Normal documentation of a PropForth word is
a comment line which shows how it changes the stack.</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ + ( n1 n2 -- n1+n2 ) \ sum of n1 &amp;
n2</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>On the left of the -- ,  is the stack
before word executes, and on the right, the stack after the word executes. Once
again, the rightmost numbers are the top of the stack.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168421"><span lang=EN-US>3.4<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Forth Words - Part 1</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The best way to understand a word is to run
the examples. The words are introduced in order of use in the examples. The
first comment line is the documentation on the word. The next line is what is
typed at the prompt. The remaining is the output.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The examples are ordered to give an
introduction to PropForth, and introduce the words and concepts so you can
start programming. Feel free to start experimenting whenever you like, it is
the purpose of PropForth to help you experiment.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>/ is a signed integer divide. There is a u/

<h2><a name="_Toc322168430"><span lang=EN-US>3.5<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Defining new words</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The following examples show how to define
new words. Once a word is defined, it is immediately available. This capability
allows you try new things quickly . As a rule, defined words should be no more
than 20 or 30  lines, most should only be a few lines.</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ new word example1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>: add37 37 + ; sc 1 2 3 cr st? add37 cr st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>0 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_002
0_000_000_003</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_002
0_000_000_040</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The : (COLON) indicates that we are
starting a definition, it is followed by a space, then the name of our new
word. We then type what we want the word to do, and end the definition of our
new word with a ; (SEMICOLON).</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ new word example2</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>: times9 9 * ; sc 1 2 40 cr st? times9 cr
st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>3 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_002
0_000_000_040</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_002
0_000_000_360</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>We can use the words we defined just as we
use native forth words.</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ new word example3</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>: add37times9 add37 times9 ; sc 1 2 3 cr
st? add37times9 cr st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>3 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_002
0_000_000_003</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_002
0_000_000_360</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168431"><span lang=EN-US>3.6<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Memory</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Before we proceed, a short discussion on
memory. The propeller has 32k bytes of main memory that is accessible to all
the cogs. Each cog has 512 32bit longs which are only accessible to the
individual cogs.</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168432"><span lang=EN-US>3.6.1  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> </span></span><span
lang=EN-US>Cog Memory</span></a></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>In cog memory, PropForth has the assembler
instructions for the interpreter, the space for the stack, and the space for
the return stack, temporary variables, and the assembler word page area, which
will be discussed later.  This takes up 320 longs. There are 16 special
registers in each cog, so this leaves 176 long which are available. Cog memory
is accessible as 32bit longs.</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168433"><span lang=EN-US>3.6.2  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> </span></span><span
lang=EN-US>Main Memory</span></a></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>In main memory, there are 8 special areas
of 224 bytes of length each, which are dedicated to the PropForth interpreter
running on each cog. The rest of main memory is used by the forth dictionary.
The forth dictionary is the forth words and their definitions. When the
interpreter gets input from the prompt, it looks up the words in the
dictionary, and executes the definition. If it does not find the word
definition, it attempts to interpret it as a number. If this succeeds the
number goes on the stack.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Variables and constants are also defined in
the forth dictionary.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Main memory is accessible as 8bit bytes,
16bit words, or 32bit longs.</span></p>

<h4><span lang=EN-US>3.6.2.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Variables</span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Variables in main memory are normally
defined as either 16bit words, or 32bit longs.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To define a 16bit word variable:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>wvariable name_of_variable</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To define a long variable</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>variable name_of_variable</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Most variables in PropForth are 16bit
variables. This save a lot of space in PropForth, but a 16 bit variable is a
positive number between 0 and 65,535. For many uses this is adequate. If you
need positive numbers larger than 65,535 or you need negative numbers, you must
use longs.</span></p>

<h4><span lang=EN-US>3.6.2.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Constants</span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Like variables, constants in main memory
are normally defined as either 16bit words, or 32bit longs.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To define a 16-bit word constant, the value
is on top of the stack:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>value wconstant name_of_constant</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To define a long constant, the value is on
the top of the stack:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>value constant name_of_constant</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168434"><span lang=EN-US>3.7<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Forth Words - Part 2</span></a></h2>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168435"><span lang=EN-US>3.7.1  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> </span></span><span
lang=EN-US>hex</span></a></h3>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ hex ( -- ) set the base for hexadecimal</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc 0 1 -1 10 100 cr st? cr hex cr st?
decimal</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>0 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_000 0_000_000_001
-0_000_000_001 0_000_000_010 0_000_000_100</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0000_0000 0000_0001 FFFF_FFFF
0000_000A 0000_0064</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Hexadecimal mode is useful when interfacing
to propeller registers or peripheral registers. PropForth can support any base
from 2 (binary) to 64. The most common are 10 (decimal) 16 (hex). These have
native words that set the base. For other bases, such as 8 (octal) for PDP11
programmers, or 2 (binary),  use: n base W! This sets the base to n, and all
numbers will be printed in that base. This can give some pretty strange looking
numbers but it is very useful as we will see later.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When using n base W! to set the base,
remember one cannot use 10 base W! to set the base back to decimal, because 10
represents a different value in each base (10 always represents the base value
in every base).&nbsp; Use d_10 base W!  or the word decimal.</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168436"><span lang=EN-US>3.7.2  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> </span></span><span
lang=EN-US>decimal</span></a></h3>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ decimal ( -- ) set the base for decimal</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc hex 0 1 FFFF_FFFF A 64 cr st? decimal cr
st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>5 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0000_0000 0000_0001 FFFF_FFFF
0000_000A 0000_0064</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_000 0_000_000_001
-0_000_000_001 0_000_000_010 0_000_000_100</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168437"><span lang=EN-US>3.7.3  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> </span></span><span
lang=EN-US>COG@</span></a></h3>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ COG@ ( addr -- n1 ) \ fetch 32 bit
value at cog addr</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc cnt cr st? cr COG@ st? cr u. cnt COG@ cr
u. cr</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>sc cnt cr st? cr COG@ st? cr u. cnt
COG@ cr u. cr</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>0 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_497</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: -2_113_416_610</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>2181550686</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>2182562366</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The cnt register, in cog memory, is a high
speed 32bit counter  incrementing once every clock cycle. Normally with a
propeller running at 80Mhz, it increments once every 12.5 nanoseconds. This
register wraps around to zero about every 53.7 seconds at 80 Mhz.</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168438"><span lang=EN-US>3.7.4  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> </span></span><span
lang=EN-US>COG!</span></a></h3>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ COG! ( n1 addr -- ) \ store 32 bit
value (n1) at cog addr</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc outa cr st? cr COG@ st? cr 1 or outa st?
cr COG! st? cr outa COG@ st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>1 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_500</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_000</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_500</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST:</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Each cog has an outa register, in this case
we are reading the value, setting bit 0 to 1, and writing the value. If the
dira register bit 0 is set to 1 as well, the value of the outa register, will
be or’d with all the other cogs outa registers bit 0 with dira registers bit 0,
and appear on io pin 0.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Normally, one cog has a pin set to output,
so the value on the io pin is corresponds to the bit in that cog’s outa
register.</span></p>

lang=EN-US>L!</span></a></h3>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ L! ( n1 addr -- ) \ store 32 bit value
(n1) at main memory addr</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc variable tmp1 -1 tmp1 cr st? cr L! st?
cr tmp1 st? cr L@ st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: -0_000_000_001</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>32bit long addresses must be long aligned. In
this example, the forth word &quot;variable&quot; uses the next text string it
encourters (in this case &quot;tmp1&quot;) and defines&nbsp; a 32bit variable
using that string as the name. Now when tmp1 is entered it returns the address
of the variable. This is how we store values to a memory location using a

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>16bit word addresses must be word aligned.
Note that when there is a -1 on the stack it corresponds to h_FFFF_FFFF. When

this corresponds to d_65_535. Generally 16bit words are used unsigned values

<h2><a name="_Toc322168456"><span lang=EN-US>3.8<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Strings</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>In PropForth strings are stored as a series
of bytes, where the first byte is the unsigned length of the string, and the
bytes of the string immediately follow. String can be from 0 to 255 bytes long,
and they consume 1 to 256 bytes of memory. To declare a string, c&quot;
string_characters&quot; is used. The c&quot; is followed by a space which is
not part of the string, and ends with &quot; which is not part of the string.
When a string is declared at the prompt, it is only valid until that line is
finished executing, as it is in temp storage. When a string is declared in a
word definition, the string will be written to the dictionary, and will be
valid until reboot.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>If we wish to embed non printable

string. Since the number is interpreted according to the current settings, is
best use ~hxx where xx are 2 valid hex digits.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168461"><span lang=EN-US>3.10<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Control Flow</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>These words are only valid while defining a
word. They are not valid at the prompt.</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168462"><span lang=EN-US>3.10.1  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>if then</span></a></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>If the value on top of the stack is any
value other than 0, execute the words between if and then. If the value is
zero, jump to the word after then.</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168463"><span lang=EN-US>3.10.2  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>if else then</span></a></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>If the value on top of the stack is any
value other than 0, execute the words between if and else. If the value is
zero, execute the words between else and then.</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168464"><span lang=EN-US>3.10.3  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>begin until</span></a></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>until will check the value on top of the
stack. If it is 0, it will jump back to begin, otherwise it will continue with
the word following until.</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168465"><span lang=EN-US>3.10.4  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>do loop</span></a></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>hiboundary loboudary do xxx loop. This will
increment from loboundary, and execute xxx until the value reaches hiboundary
-1. Between the do and loop, the word i will put the current loop counter on
the top of the stack.</span></p>

</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Talking to the other cogs</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Up until this point we have been
interacting with cog 6. What about the rest of the cogs?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When PropForth starts up, it starts a

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When we are connected to cog 6, and we type
in 5 &gt;con(ENTER), we connect the console to the cog 5. Because input to a
cog has a buffer of one character, if we type quickly enough the first
character following may be sent to the currently connected cog. So we make sure
to type 2 additional enters. The first additional enter will be consumed by cog
6, and the second by cog 5. Realistically, if you are typing, this will not be
an issue, but if you paste in text, or are sending it programmatically, this
can occur.</span></p>

</span></span><span lang=EN-US>.const?</span></a></h3>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US style='color:#9BBB59'>\ .const? (

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>c&quot; sc 111 222 333 .const?&quot;

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>If a cog does not have the console

another cog.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>We set one cog modifying a signal with a
cycle of one second, and we set another cog looking at the signal 5 times a
second. If the signal is changing more often than we are looking at it, it is
pretty obvious we are going to miss some changes. This an important concept
when sampling signals, we need to look at the signal at least twice as rapidly
as it is changing (search the web for Nyquist and sampling for details). If we
need to see the signal edges in relation to other signals, we will need to
sample more rapidly.  To start looking at this in more detail, we will need to
cover LogicAnalyzer.  This is a PropForth tool that looks at the pins and displays
them graphically.</span></p>

<h1><a name="_Toc322168491"><span lang=EN-US>5<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>LogicAnalyzer</span></a></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When we need to look at changing io pins,
and understand what they are doing, Logic Analyzer that looks at the pins a
user determined intervals, and store the results. It can only understand if a
pin is hi or lo, if it is left as a floating input, it may appear as either, or
as changing. When Logic Analyzer samples, it either uses cog memory for fast
sampling or free dictionary memory for slower sampling. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Logic Analyzer has 2 flavors, a console
mode, invoked by the word lac, and words which you can call directly from the
command line or other words. We will cover the console mode.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To use Logic Analyzer and be able to
correctly interpret what you are seeing there are a few concepts to cover.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The first is triggering, when does it start
sampling. It can start sampling on the rising edge of a pin, then falling edge
of a pin, or it can ignore the trigger, and sample as soon as it is ready
(trigger NONE). For lac, if a pin it not changing rapidly enough, a few times a
second, lac will not be able to determine the frequency of the trigger. In this
case it will ignore the trigger setting and sample when it is ready. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Sample Interval is the next important item.
This is what defines how often lac looks at the pins. Look too slowly, and you
will miss something, look too quickly and you may not get the big picture. We
will see examples of both.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The user interface of lac uses single keys
to change values and start sampling. It requires an ANSI terminal, as it
running in full screen. A previous version of lac had a much more elaborate
interface, but it consumed too much memory, and thus did not have adequate
space for the samples.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168492"><span lang=EN-US>5.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Loading lac</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>In the download of PropForth, in the
directory CurrentRelease\Extensions, open the file lac.f and paste the contents
in the terminal.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>If you wish to have lac always available,
type in saveforth, this will save the running image to eeprom, and lac wil be
available after rebooting.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168493"><span lang=EN-US>5.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Running lac</span></a></h2>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>lac</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>    Trigger Pin      -q    +Q: 0</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>   Trigger Edge   -w +W SPACE: __--</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Trigger Frequency         eE :</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Sample Interval -asdfg +ASDFG: 500.0
nS             40 clock cycles</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>         Sample     &lt;ENTER&gt;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>         Quit         &lt;ESC&gt;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Sample Display  -zxcv  +ZXCV
:                 clock cycles of             128</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Starting from the top, the trigger pin is
currently pin 0. Q will decrement this number and Q will increment this number.
When this pin changes, depending on other settings is when we will start
sampling.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The trigger edge indicates we are looking
for a low to high transition on this pin, w, W  and space will set this setting
to  --__ or --__ or NONE. When we set this to NONE, there are no specific
criteria for when we start sampling.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The trigger Frequency is set when the
trigger pin changes, or e or E is hit. lac will look at the trigger pin for
about 250 msec to try to calculate the trigger frequency. If E is hit, it will
look at the pin for a about a second to calculate the trigger frequency. If the
pin is changing slower than once per second, lac may not detect the frequency.
If lac does not detect the frequency, it will behave like trigger is set to
NONE. This is to prevent it from waiting forever for a change which will not
happen.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Sample interval is the next field. This
defines how often we are going to look at the pins. lac will run in a few
different modes depending on what this value. The most important item to note
is that if you set it to sample at every clock cycle, it will reset cogs 2-5
and use them to do the sampling. (This parameter can be set to any 4 sequential
cogs). In all other cases only the current cog is used. All the pins on the
cogs used by current cog (or 2-5) are set to be inputs. This may seem obvious,
but if you set a pin to output, and set it high, and then run lac, lac will
change that pin to an input to sample it. The sampling interval is changed by
the keys a-g and A-G. Lower case decrements the interval and upper case
increments it. a and A change it by one cycle, and g-G by 10,000 cycles, with
the keys in between changing it by 10, 100, and 1000.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>If you want to exit lac, hit ESC. To have
lac sample and display hit ENTER.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Sample Display tells which samples of the
total sample you are looking at. To scroll the sample display use zxcv ZXCV.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Now for an example, we are going to define
a simple program which increment pins. Enter / paste in the following and hit
enter to get lac to sample.</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ pinIncrementer( n1 ) increment 8 pins
starting at pin n1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>: pinIncrement</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>  hFF over lshift dira COG!</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>  0 begin</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>    1+ 2dup swap lshift outa COG!</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>  0 until</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>c&quot; 0 pinIncrement&quot; 0
cogx </span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>lac</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>We should see something like the following,
notice that we only see one transition, so we are not really getting a good
picture of what is going on.</span><span lang=EN-US> </span><img width=1024
height=600 id="Picture 7" src="PropForth_files/image001.png"></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Change the Trigger Pin to pin 7, the
Trigger Edge to --__and set the sample to 1000 clock cycles, and resample. Now
we get a much better picture of what is going on. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><img width=1024 height=600 id="Picture 10"
src="PropForth_files/image002.png"></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Now if we hit C twice, we can look at the
signals further along. This gives us a fair bit of detail, and still see a
large enough picture.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><img width=1024 height=600 id="Picture 13"
src="PropForth_files/image003.png"></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Note that when you scroll the Sample
Display, it will stay there when you resample. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Remember that lac is just looking at the
pins every sample interval as specified, and then allowing us to look at them
graphically. If we sample too fast or slow, we will not have a good picture of
what is happening. Try to get a few samples at different rates to understand
how this can affect thing.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Sampling too slow can really give us a bad
picture, which can be very misleading. Here is the same signal sampled every
20,000 cycles. It look like pin 0 is changing at the same rate as pin 6. We are
sampling way too slow, and we happen to be sampling at a frequency that makes
pin 0 look ok, but is really very wrong. This undersampling can lead to bad
information. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><img width=1024 height=600 id="Picture 16"
src="PropForth_files/image004.png"></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Undersampling is one of the most common errors
leading to bad information, remember to sample and look at the signal at
multiple sample rates.</span></p>

<h1><a name="_Toc322168494"><span lang=EN-US>6<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>PropForth Input/Output</span></a></h1>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168495"><span lang=EN-US>6.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Overview</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>A PropForth cog by default has a single
character IO channel. This channel consists of a character input channel and a 
character output channel. The input channel is where input is received and
interpreted by PropForth, and the output channel is where the interpreter
echoes characters, and sends any output. This IO channel is a synchronous
channel. When a cog’s output channel is not connected, the output is thrown
away. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>In normal operation a cog’s output channel
is connected to another cog’s input channel. This is a synchronous operation. A
cog will output only as fast as the connected cog will receive characters.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When PropForth starts, cog 7 is repurposed
as a serial cog. Cog 7’s IO channel is buffered and received/sent to the serial
driver pins. The serial driver has a circular receive buffer of 128 bytes, and
a circular transmit buffer of 64 bytes. When a character is received on the
serial line, it is put in the next free position in the receive buffer. If the
receive buffer is full, it wraps around and starts overwriting the buffer. If
the output channel is not connected, the serial driver throws away the
characters received. However, if it is connected, it will synchronously send
the next available character to the connected cog.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Normal startup is to connect the serial
driver to cog 6.  The cog? word is one way to see this.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>cog?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>Cog:0  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:1  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:2  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:3  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:4  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:5  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:6  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1  6(0)-&gt;7(0)</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:7  #io
chan:1                           SERIAL  7(0)-&gt;6(0)</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>This word looks at each cog, and prints out
how many IO channels the cog has, a string of what the cog is running, and its
IO connections. Most times a cog will have only one IO channel. The exception
is a cog running an IP server, or MCS (Multi Channel Synchronous)
communications. If we look at cog 7, it tells us that 7(0) (cog 7 channel 0)
-&gt; (is connected to) 6(0) (cog 6 channel 0). This means serial driver is sending
the characters it receives to cog 6. Conversely, cog 6 is sending its output to
cog 7’s input, which the serial driver buffers and transmits.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>fl takes the input it is receiving, strips
out comments, and comment blocks, strips leading whitespace, buffers it, and
simultaneously send it to another cog to process. This allows PropForth to
accept input faster than it can interpret or compile it. So in this case we see

send the characters to cog 5, who does the actual processing of the input, and
send it’s output to cog 7, who buffers and transmits over the serial line.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>    if</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>      h_20 -</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168496"><span lang=EN-US>6.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Technical details</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Each cog has 224 bytes of main memory which
hold a number of variables. This cog data area has the beginning the IO channel
which PropForth uses for input and output. The IO channel is 2 words, the first
word is the input character to PropForth. The second word is a pointer to an
input channel, or zero if the channel is not connected.</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168497"><span lang=EN-US>6.2.1  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> </span></span><span
lang=EN-US>Input Word</span></a></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When another cog wants to send input to
another cogs, it waits until the value of that cog’s input word is h_0100. It
then writes a word with the value h_00xx where xx is the character value.  The
receiving cog waits until the h_0100 anded with the input word is zero, and it
then accepts the character. When it is ready to accept another character, it
write h_0100 to the word. This is how all the PropForth IO words read a
character. </span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ io  ( -- addr ) the address of the io
channel for the cog</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc io st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>0 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_002_184</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Obviously this will return a different
value for each cog, if we need another cog’s IO channel / data area:</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ cogio ( n -- addr) the address of the
data area for cog n</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc 0 cogio 1 cogio 2 cogio st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>0 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_840 0_000_001_064
0_000_001_288</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ input demo, send the key 5 to cog 0</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc 0 cogreset 10 delms hex 0 cogio W@ st? drop
h_35 0 cogio W! 0 cogio W@ st? decimal</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>0 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>CON:Prop0 Cog0 RESET - last status: 0
ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0000_0100</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0000_0100</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Cog 0 is waiting for input, when we write a
character, cog 0 accept it, and writes h_0100 back. The io routines in
PropForth and optimized in assembler, so the time it takes cog 0 to accept the
word, and be ready for another word is very short. So we will make cog 0 busy.</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ input demo, send the key 5 to cog 0,
after we make it busy</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>sc 0 cogreset 10 delms hex</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>: busy begin 0 until ;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>c&quot; busy&quot; 0 cogx</span></p>

W! 0 cogio W@ st?</span></p>

<h3><a name="_Toc322168498"><span lang=EN-US>6.2.2  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> </span></span><span
lang=EN-US>Output Pointer</span></a></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US>The second word of the IO channel is a pointer. If the pointer is
zero, all the output to the IO channel is discarded. This prevents a cog from
blocking. When a cog is connected, it will point to the input word of the
channel.</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ cog ouput pointer example</span></p>

st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:0  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:1  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:2  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:3  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:4  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:5  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:6  #io chan:1 PropForth v5.0
2012JAN09 14:30 1  6(0)-&gt;7(0)</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:7  #io
chan:1                           SERIAL  7(0)-&gt;6(0)</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_000 0_000_002_408
0_000_002_408</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>We can see that the output pointer of cog 5

cogio st?</span></p>

2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

2012JAN09 14:30 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Cog:7  #io
chan:1                           SERIAL  7(0)-&gt;5(0)</span></p>

0_000_002_408</span></p>
