<h3><a name="_Toc322168499"><span lang=EN-US>6.2.3  <span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> </span></span><span
lang=EN-US>Advanced topics</span></a></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Each PropForth cog has a single IO channel.
A serial driver running on a cog has one IO channel as well. This is channel
zero, and in most cases the only channel. There are cases where a cog is
running a driver that has more than one channel. Two examples of this are the
MCS driver, and the IP server.</span></p>

<h4><span lang=EN-US>6.2.3.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>MCS (Multi Channel Synchronous) Driver</span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>MCS is a driver that uses 2 pins to provide
8 full duplex IO channels to another propeller running MCS. In this case the
cog running MCS has an array of 8 IO channels, starting where the normal IO
channel resides. This means that when we want to address an MCS channel, we
need to specify the cog running MCS, and which channel we wish to address. The
native PropForth words which require both the cog and the channel to be
specified (ioconn) (iodis) (iolink) (iounlink). The words ioconn, iodis,
iolink, iounlink calls these words with a channel number of zero. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>For further details see the MCS
documentation.</span></p>

<h4><span lang=EN-US>6.2.3.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>IP Server</span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The IP server interfaces to the WIZNET
W5100 to provide 4 Internet Protocol channels. Like any channel, these can
connect to cogs and provide IO. In the case when all the channels are started
as telnet channels, each channel can connect to a cog. This allows talking to 4
cogs at the same time with 4 telnet sessions. Very handy for some applications.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>For further details see the IP
documentation. </span></p>

<h1><a name="_Toc322168500"><span lang=EN-US>7<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>PropForth Assembler</span></a></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The propeller has a unique architecture and
PropForth was written to match the architecture. Using assembler on the
propeller is not the same as using assembler on a more conventional architecture,
and it is very different than a CISC  architecture like what you find in your
PC. Firstly each cog has 496 registers that are accessible only to that cog for
instructions and data. Each cog can rely on the fact that only it can modify
those registers, short of the cog being reset externally. In addition, each cog
will never be interrupted, it will continually execute and it can decide when
to access main memory or not. This can give each cog a high degree of isolation
from the other cogs.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>PropForth is an easy way to explore the
propeller assembler, short words can be defined, and executed and the results
can be easily integrated into normal PropForth words, or they can be used
interactively via the console. While this does not change the complexity of
assembler code, it does provide an easy interface to that code. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>One of the changes in PropForth v5.0 was
the way in which assembler words are defined and used. An assembler word is
defined, and can be invoked just like any other forth word. The assembler code
is automatically paged in to cog memory and executed. This allowed the
definition of many more assembler words, without using more cog memory.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The result was many more words defined as
assembler words, and the overall kernel speed was greatly improved, and total
cog memory usage went down.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To understand how to use assembler words,
it is necessary to understand how they fit into the kernel.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168501"><span lang=EN-US>7.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Kernels and Assembler Words</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>PropForth starts life as
PropForthStartKernel. This kernel has no assembler words defined, has all the
symbols defined, is slow to interpret or compile anything, has error detection,
and  no error reporting. The cog memory usage is small. It uses a total of 274
cog longs, and 13,594 main memory bytes. The cog memory usage includes:</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>32 longs for the main stack</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>32 longs for the return stack</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>6 longs for temporary registers tregone -
tregsix</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>5 longs for constants, fDestInc, fCondMask,
fMask, fAddrMask, fLongMask</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>1 long for the a register used for reset,
resetDreg</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>1 long used for the interpreter instruction
pointer, IP</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>1 long for the stack pointer, stPtr</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>1 long for the return stack pointer, rsPtr</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>1 long for the top of stack value, stTOS</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>194 longs for the forth interpreter</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>This leaves a total of 222 cog longs free
(512 -16 (special purpose regs) - 274 (PropForth regs). The only use for this
kernel is to build other kernels. The first useful kernel, is
PropForthBootKernel. This kernel removes the symbols which are necessary for
rebuilding the start kernel, but are used infrequently. They can be dynamically
defined as needed. The PropForthBootKernel uses 274 cog longs and 12646 main
memory bytes. This kernel is still slow to interpret or compile code, but is
fully functional. It is used as the base for PropForthOptimizeBootKernel. We
start with PropForthBootKernel, and define a number of assembler words which
will greatly speed up the kernel. Words like _accept, which reads an input line
from the console, _dictsearch, which searches the dictionary, and a number of
other words. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>All the words are assembled to load at cog
address 274, the initial value of the wvariable coghere which the first free
long in cog memory.  </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When a word is assembled, the first long in
the assembler definition is constructed as follows:</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Bits 31 - 19 (14 bits) - correspond to the 14 hi
bits in main memory where the assembler word is defined, since it is always
long aligned the 2 low bits will always be 0</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Bits 18 - 9 (9 bits) - the number of longs in
this assembler words</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Bits 8 - 0 (9 bits) - the starting cog address
of this assembler word</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>When the PropForth interpreter encounters
an assembler word, it checks the first word of the definition against the
starting cog address of the assembler word, if it matches, the assembler code
for this word is already loaded, and the assembler code is executed. If it does
not match, it loads the code from main memory, and then executes the assembler
code. This simple mechanism allows PropForth to page in and cache assembler words
into cog memory.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The kernel build process, looks at all the
assembler words to and generates a word, init_coghere, which defines the new
free cog starting address. This means the area between cog address 274, and 320
is used as the area where the kernel loads assembler words . This leaves room
for the largest assembler word defined in the boot optimization process
(_accept).</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The new kernel, PropForthOptimizeBootKernel
incorporates the assembler optimizations. This kernel uses 320 cog longs and
13,262 byte of main memory. If is fast to interpret and compile, but does not
have any error reporting. This is added and the release kernel(s) are
generated. The release kernels do not consume more cog memory but they do
consume more main memory. The starting address for the area where the assembler
words are paged is defined by the constant build_BootOpt. The end of the page
area is defined by the initial value of the wvariable coghere, which is 320. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US> Any assembler word which is to be paged in
and out of this portion of cog memory, must then be defined to start at the
address build_bootOpt, and be less than 46 longs. If the assembler word never
returns, like _serial, which starts a serial driver on the cog, it can be
longer than 46 longs, as nothing else will ever have the opportunity to be
paged in.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>If nothing else is using the cog memory,
and the page area is overflowed, this will be a bug that doesn’t show up, until
something uses the free cog memory, like the sd card forth code.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>So the rules for assembler words; the start
address if defined by build_BootOpt, and the end address must be before the
initial value of coghere. If these rules are followed, there is no danger of a
problem.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>LogicAnalyzer breaks these rules, the
faster sampling routines (sampling faster than every 41 cycles) uses the cog
memory to store samples, so if you use LogicAnalyzer on the same cogs as the sd
card driver, there will be strange effects. The original LogicAnalyzer was
written before these rules were established. All of the other optimizations in
the sd card driver or the ipserver follow the rules with no problems. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Some programmers may quickly deduce that
this mechanism can allow for multiple page areas in each cog. This capability
can allow for multiple cache sets in each cogs memory. This capability has not
yet been explored by the PropForth kernel.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168502"><span lang=EN-US>7.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Writing Assembler Words</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The interactive nature of PropForth guides
us when to use assembler. Generally the development cycle it to write forth
words, verify the development functionality, and then rewrite some of the forth
words in assembler to get the performance we need or want, and then of course re-verify
the functionality. This has been the development cycle for the kernel and
extensions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To illustrate how to use the assembler we
will generate some simple artificial examples, which illustrate the concepts.
To use the assembler, load asm.f from the CurrentRelease/Extensions directory,
and if you like do a saveforth.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>A PropForth assembler word is always in the
form:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>build_BootOpt :rasm</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>    jexit</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>;asm noop</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create noop forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h114  h113  1- tuck - h9
lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z1SV01X l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>In the input,  build_BootOpt is the
constant which defines the starting address to load this word, :rasm starts the
assembler definition, jexit is an assembler macro (more on macros later) which
returns control to the PropForth interpreter, and ;asm noop ends the definition
and names  the word noop  .</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The assembler does not define the word, it
emits the definition which is used to define the word. The first line locks the
dictionary and defines the dictionary entry, adds the forth interpreter code
for assembler definitions, and generates the first long of the assembler
definition. Recall, the first long defines the address in main memory where the
definition resides, the starting address in cog memory, and the number of longs
in the definition.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Then follow the longs which are the
assembler code. These are output as base 64 numbers, this is the most compact
representation. If you really want to see hex change the line:</span></p>

<p class=Code><span lang=EN-US>h7A emit base W@ h40 base W! swap u. base W!</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>to:</span></p>

<p class=Code><span lang=EN-US>h68 emit base W@ h10 base W! swap u. base W!</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>in asm.f</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>And the last line frees the dictionary.
Since multiple cogs can update the dictionary, the definition must start and
end with no other cogs able to update the dictionary. This is accomplished by
lockdict / freedict.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Now we can take the assembler definition
and paste it into the console, and run the word.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create noop forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h114  h113  1- tuck
- h9 lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z1SV01X l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create noop forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h114  h113  1- tuck - h9
lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z1SV01X l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>noop</span></p>

<p class=Code><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Not a functionally exciting example, but we
have generates an assembler word which can be automatically paged in and out as
needed.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The assembler generates a definition which
we can load, without having the assembler present. This is great, but it will
get a little tedious to have to</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168503"><span lang=EN-US>7.3<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>The Stack in Detail</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To write useful assembler words, we need to
understand the stack and how to manipulate it with assembler. In the execution
of an assembler word, there are six temporary registers available for use. The
contents of these registers is undefined every time the word is called. Some of
these registers are commoly used in stack manipulations, and they are referred
to as $C_treg1 - $C_treg6 . </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The $C_ prefix indicated this refers to an
address in cog memory, and the forth kernel rebuild procedure updates these as
necessary when kernels are rebuilt.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The value on the top of the stack is held
in a register called $C_stTOS . The first example we will generate is a very
simple operation which changes the value on the top of the stack.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>build_BootOpt :rasm</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>     add    $C_stTOS , # d_256</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>    jexit</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>;asm add256</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create add256 forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h115  h113  1- tuck - h9
lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z20yPS0 l, z1SV01X l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>All assembler mnemonics are lower case and
are delimited by spaces, the next field is the destination register also
delimited by spaces, and the next field is the source register, also delimited
by spaces. The # indicates the following value is an immediate value, as opposed
to the register location. Immediate values in assembler instructions are
numbers between 0 and 511 inclusively. Any numbers used in an assembler
definition should explicitly define the base as decimal, hex, binary or base64.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Now we define the example:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create add256 forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h115  h113  1- tuck
- h9 lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z20yPS0 l, z1SV01X l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create add256 forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h115  h113  1- tuck - h9
lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z20yPS0 l, z1SV01X l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>And run some tests:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc 0 st? add256 st? add256 st? -100 add256
st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>0 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_000</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_256</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_512</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_512 0_000_000_156</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Now we will deal with multiple items on the
stack, but first the assembler macros. Assembler macros are defined in asm.f,
and there are a few defined which are used repeatedly, we have already used
one, which is jexit. Macros are just shorthand for an assembler instruction
with specific source and destination.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><b><span lang=EN-US>jexit</span></b><span lang=EN-US> - <b>jmp   
$C_a_exit</b> - jumps to the PropForth interpreter assembler code which is
executed when an assembler word in finished execution</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><b><span lang=EN-US>spush</span></b><span lang=EN-US> - <b>jmpret   
$C_a_stpush_ret , $C_a_stpush</b> - calls a subroutine which pushes the
register $C_a_stTOS onto the stack, after which $C_a_stTOS must be set to  a
new value. This subroutine will cause a reset error if the stack is overflowed.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><b><span lang=EN-US>spopt</span></b><span lang=EN-US> - <b>jmpret   
$C_a_stpoptreg_ret , $C_a_stpoptreg</b> - moves the register $C_a_stTOS into
$C_a_treg1, and pops on item off the stack into $C_a_stTOS. This subroutine
will cause a reset error if the stack is underflowed.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><b><span lang=EN-US>rpush</span></b><span lang=EN-US> - <b>jmpret
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$C_a_rspush_ret , $C_a_rspush</b> - pushes the value in
$C_treg5 onto the return stack. This subroutine will cause a reset error if the
return stack is overflowed.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast style='margin-left:72.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><b><span lang=EN-US>rspop</span></b><span lang=EN-US> - <b>jmpret
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$C_a_rspop_ret , $C_a_rspop</b> - pops &nbsp;a &nbsp;value
from the return stack into $C_treg5. This subroutine will cause a reset error
if the return stack is underflowed.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Normally the spush, spop, spopt, and jexit
are the only macros used. The return stack is where the interpreter stores the
addresses of the words it needs to execute when the current word is done. If
they are tampered with, havoc will result. It is useful to be able to put
things on the return stack, and remove them, but care should be taken, just as
when using the forth r&gt; and &gt;r words. Now we will define an example that
uses the top two stack items.</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ cmpsubtest ( n1 n2 - n3) if n1 is
greater than or equal to n2, n3 = n1 - n2, otherwise n3 = n1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>build_BootOpt :rasm</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; spopt</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
cmpsub&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_stTOS , $C_treg1 wr</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; jexit</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>;asm cmpsubtest</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create cmpsubtest forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h116&nbsp; h113&nbsp; 1-
tuck - h9 lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z1SyLIZ l, z3WiPRC l, z1SV01X l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The first instruction, spopt, pops a value
off the stack (n2), and puts it in $C_treg1. The value in $C_a_stTOS is now n1.
The assembler instruction, cmpsub, subtracts the source value from the
destination value if the source is greater than or equal to the destination.
Note the use of wr, to explicitly write the result. When the assembler was
first written, the reference used was the Propeller Manual version 1.01. In
that reference the cmpsub instruction did not write the result by default. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The assembler supports, wr, nr, wz, and wc
as instruction postfix operators.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To prevent the result from being written in
the destination register, use nr, to write the result in the destination
register, use wr, to write the z-flag ,use wz, and to write the c-flag, use wc.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Now we define the example:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create cmpsubtest
forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h116&nbsp;
h113&nbsp; 1- tuck - h9 lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z1SyLIZ l, z3WiPRC l, z1SV01X l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create cmpsubtest forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h116&nbsp; h113&nbsp; 1-
tuck - h9 lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z1SyLIZ l, z3WiPRC l, z1SV01X l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>And run some tests:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc 10 9 cmpsubtest st? 10 11 cmpsubtest st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>0 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_010</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>One more stack example,</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ hibitset? ( n1 - n1 n2) n2 is the
highest bit set in n1, -1 if there are not bits set</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>fl</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>build_BootOpt :rasm</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ $C_treg3 is a loop counter</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ $C_treg2 is the return value,
which we initialize to -1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ $C_treg1 is a mask with one bit
on, to test n1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>mov&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_treg3 ,
# d32</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>mov&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_treg1 ,
__valhi</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>mov&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_treg2 ,
__minusone</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>__loop</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ if the bit is NOT on in n1, the
z-flag will be true (1)</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;test&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_stTOS , $C_treg1 wz</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ </span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ if the zflag was NOT set, it
means we have a 1 bit in n1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ set the return value to the
loop counter - 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>if_nz&nbsp;&nbsp;
mov&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_treg2 , $C_treg3</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>if_nz&nbsp;&nbsp;
sub&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_treg2 , # 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ </span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ if the zflag was set, it means
we have a 0 bit in n1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ shift the mask register right,
and loop</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>if_z&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
shr&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_treg1 , # 1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>if_z&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
djnz&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_treg3 , # __loop</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ push n1 down on the stack</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>spush</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ and set the new top of stack to
the return value</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>mov&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; $C_stTOS ,
$C_treg2</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>jexit</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ the variables which we will use</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>__valhi</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>h_8000_0000</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>__minusone</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>-1</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>;asm hibitset?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create hibitset? forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h120  h113  1- tuck - h9
lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z2WyPjW l, z2WiP[U l, z2WiPfV l,
z1YFPRC l, z2W\PeE l, z24oPb1 l, zbtPW1 l, z3[tPnM l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z1SyJQL l, z2WiPRD l, z1SV01X l,
z200000 l, z3yyyyy l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog5 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>In  assembler words,  labels start with __
. A long can be initialized with a value as shown in  __valhi and __minusone.
All the prefix operators can be used in the assembler as well.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Now to define the example:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>fl</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create hibitset?
forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h120&nbsp;
h113&nbsp; 1- tuck - h9 lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z2WyPjW l, z2WiP[U l, z2WiPfV l,
z1YFPRC l, zbyPW1 l, z2W\PeE l, z24oPb1 l, z3[tPnM l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z1SyJQL l, z2WiPRD l, z1SV01X l,
z200000 l, z3yyyyy l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US style='color:#4F81BD'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>fl</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog5 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>lockdict create hibitset? forthentry</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog5 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$C_a_lxasm w, h120  h113  1- tuck - h9
lshift or here W@ alignl h10 lshift or l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog5 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z2WyPjW l, z2WiP[U l, z2WiPfV l,
z1YFPRC l, zbyPW1 l, z2W\PeE l, z24oPb1 l, z3[tPnM l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog5 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>z1SyJQL l, z2WiPRD l, z1SV01X l,
z200000 l, z3yyyyy l,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog5 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>freedict</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog5 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog5 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>And run some tests:</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sc -1 hibitset? st? 2drop 2 hibitset? st?
2drop 1 hibitset? st? 2drop 0 hibitset? st?</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>0 items cleared</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: -0_000_000_001 0_000_000_031</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_002 0_000_000_001</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_001 0_000_000_000</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>ST: 0_000_000_000 -0_000_000_001</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168504"><span lang=EN-US>7.4<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>Assembler Mnemonic List</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>These are the mnemonics the assembler
recognizes. For a detailed description see the Propeller manual. The assembler
is based on V1.01. There are some changes in later versions.</span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='text-indent:-18.0pt'><span
lang=EN-US style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

<h1><a name="_Toc322168507"><span lang=EN-US>8<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>A Low Power example</span></a></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>We are going to see how we can make a
propeller go into very low power mode, and then boot up when a key is hit. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>We are low to accomplish this by stopping
all the cogs but one, and have it wait for a transition on the serial input
line.</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>fl</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ sleep ( -- ) go into low power mode
until a transition is detected on the serial input line to the cog</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>: sleep</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ print out a message, and pause, this
will allow the serial driver to output the message before we shut it down</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>  .&quot; ~h0D~h0DGOING TO SLEEP~h0D~h0D&quot;
100 delms</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ shut down all the cogs but this one</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>  8 0</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>  do</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>    i cogid &lt;&gt;</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>    if</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>      i cogstop</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>    then</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>  loop</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ make sure the serial input pin is an
input</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>  $S_rxpin pinin</span></p>

<p class=CodeCommentCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>\ n1 0 hubopr drop is the same
as a clkset, which writes to the propeller CLK register</span></p>

<p class=CodeCommentCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>\ setting the propeller CLK
register to zero, sets the main clock to RCSLOW (13 - 33Khz)</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>  0 0 hubopr drop</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ wait for the serial line to be high</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>  $S_rxpin &gt;m dup waitpeq</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ wait for the serial line to be lo</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>  $S_rxpin &gt;m dup waitpne</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ turn on the oscillator and PLL, assumes
we have a crystal/resonator of 4 - 16 Mhz</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>  h_68 0 hubopr drop</span></p>

<p class=CodeCommentCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>\ wait at least 10 millisec for
the oscillator and pll to stabilize</span></p>

<p class=CodeCommentCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>\ we are still running with a
main clock of 13 - 33Khz, so this loop is longer than 10 ms</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>  100 0</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>  do</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>  loop</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ set the clock to be 16x the crystal</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>  h_6F 0 hubopr drop</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ and execute the onboot word, this
performs the initialization sequence</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>  0 onboot drop</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>  .&quot; ~h0D~h0D AWAKE~h0D~h0D&quot;
100 delms</span></p>

<p class=CodeInputCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>fl</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>.&quot; ~h0D~h0DGOING TO SLEEP~h0D~h0D&quot;
100 delms</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>8 0</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>do</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>i cogid &lt;&gt;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>if</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>i cogstop</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>then</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>loop</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$S_rxpin pinin</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>0 0 hubopr drop</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$S_rxpin &gt;m dup waitpeq</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>$S_rxpin &gt;m dup waitpne</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>h_68 0 hubopr drop</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>100 0</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>do</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>loop</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>h_6F 0 hubopr drop</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>0 onboot drop</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>.&quot; ~h0D~h0D AWAKE~h0D~h0D&quot;
100 delms</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog5 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeComment><span lang=EN-US>\ now put the prop to sleep</span></p>

<p class=CodeInput><span lang=EN-US>sleep</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>GOING TO SLEEP</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The prop is now in low power mode, until we
hit a key.</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>CON:Prop0 Cog0 RESET - last status: 0
ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>CON:Prop0 Cog1 RESET - last status: 0
ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>CON:Prop0 Cog2 RESET - last status: 0
ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>CON:Prop0 Cog3 RESET - last status: 0
ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>CON:Prop0 Cog4 RESET - last status: 0
ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US> AWAKE</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>CON:Prop0 Cog5 RESET - last status: 0
ok</span></p>

<p class=CodeCxSpLast><span lang=EN-US>Prop0 Cog6 ok</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>According to the specs, typical current
consumption should be in the 25 micro-amp range. Will measure and update
sometime.</span></p>

<h2><a name="_Toc322168978"><span lang=EN-US>9.4<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</span></span><span lang=EN-US>SDKernel Word Set (build_sd)</span></a></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>sdfs is meant to be a very simple fast file
system on top of sd_driver.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The design criteria are around small code
size and speed, as opposed to generality and versatility.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Main concepts:</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>1. A file system occupies n contiguous 512
byte blocks on the SD card. If it is desired that the card should be FAT32
formatted, it should be possible to format card, create a very large file,
figure out which blocks the file occupies, and mount sdfs to use those blocks.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>This means sdfs could be manipulated on a
pc by writing some code. This is NOT a goal of the initial implementation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The file system must not start at block 0,
block 1 is the first valid block number.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>This also means multiple file systems can
be defined on one sd card, useful for isolating functions like logging.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>An sd card can be partitioned into multiple
&quot;disks&quot;, each which can contain one file system. There is no
partition table or disk routines, when a filesystem is created, the start and
end inherently defines the partion.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>2. Files are 2 - n contiguous blocks, the
maximum file size is 2Gig, (max positive 32 bit integer.) When a file is
created, the space that is allocated to the file (the space is  allocated as
blocks of 512 bytes) is the maximum size the file can grow to. This trades
space efficiency for a very simple and fast allocation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>3. File names must be 1 to 26 characters in
length, and can only contain characters 0h30 - 0h7D. There are no other
restrictions on file names. It is recommended that names do not use special
characters. The reason for this is mapping urls to file names gets more
complicated.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>4. There is directory support, a directory
is a fixed length file, whose name ends with a / There is no other
differentiator. A directory can contain up to 2048 entries. A simple hashing
mechanism makes navigation quick. (This hash function should be tested more
thouroughly for at some point, but initial testing seems ok.) This optimizes
for opening files, the result is that to list a directory the whole directory
must be traversed, so directory &quot;listing&quot; is slower.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>However, assuming the hash function
performs reasonably, finding a file, and opening the file file be fast, and not
slow down as there are more entries in the directory.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The root directory is /</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Pathnames are simple concatenated directory
and file names. </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>The maximum total length of a path name is
120 characters, this should make mapping urls to files very easy, and allow the
use of the pad for parsing and file name manipulation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>To access a file, or directory, the current
directory must be set to the parent of the file or directory. File access is
only in that directory. This means no relative navigation or fully qualified
file names. Reasons are 2 fold, 1 simplicity, 2 security. This will bebome
evident when the http server is using the file system.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>5. There is no limit on directory depth
other than that which is imposed by the maximum path name length. The deeper a
file is in the structure, the longer it will take to navigate to it.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>6. Each file has a header block,
immediately followed by all the data blocks.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>7. The header block number is used by
routines to reference files and directories.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>8. Block numbers are absolute, this makes
debugging, repair, and verification much simpler.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>Unfortunately it means you cannot easily
move the file system around.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span lang=EN-US>9. The main interface routines to sdfs are:</span></p>

<p class=CodeCommentCxSpFirst><span lang=EN-US>\ _sd_CrEaTe ( n1 n2 -- ) n1 -
starting block, n2 - last block + 1, CREATE a file system, WIPES OUT DATA</span></p>

<p class=CodeCommentCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=CodeCommentCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ sd_mount ( n1 -- ) mount the
file system, n1 - the starting block of the file system,</span></p>

<p class=CodeCommentCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>\ the file system must be
mounted before it is used</span></p>

<p class=CodeCommentCxSpMiddle><span lang=EN-US>&nbsp;</span></p>
